<p>C. Vid avtalets ikraftträdande skall Israel gradvis avskaffa tullar på<br>import från EFTA-länderna på de fiskprodukter som omfattas av avtalet<br>enligt följande tidtabell:</p>
<p>a) Den 1 januari 1993 - varje tullsats skall sänkas till 80 % av<br>bastullen.</p>
<p>b) Fyra ytterligare på varandra följande sänkningar på 20 % av<br>bastullen vaije år fram till avvecklingen den 1 januari 1997.</p>
<p>ANMÄRKNING</p>
<p>1. Israel åtar sig att säkerställa att det licenssystem, som för närvarande<br>tillämpas för handeln med fisk och andra marina produkter med<br>ursprung i EFTA-länderna, inte skall drabba handeln med dessa<br>länder.</p>
<p>2. Denna licensfråga skall diskuteras på Gemensamma kommitténs<br>första möte med syfte att avskaffa licenssystemet för de produkter som<br>inte är föremål för kvantitativa restriktioner.</p>
<p>193</p>
<p>13 Riksdagen 1992/93. 1 saml. Nr 22. Del 1</p>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>PROTOCOL B</p>
<p>CONCERNING THE DEFINITION OF THE CONCEPT OF &quot;ORIGINATING<br>PRODUCTS&quot; AND METHODS OF ADMINISTRATIVE CO-OPERATION</p>
<p>TITLE I</p>
<p>Definition of the concept of &quot;originating products&quot;</p>
<p>ARTICLE 1</p>
<p>For the purpose of implementing this Agreement, and without<br>prejudice to the provisions of Article 2, the following<br>products shall be considered as products originating in a<br>State Party to this Agreement:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;products wholly obtained in that State within the<br>meaning of Article 4;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;products obtained in that State incorporating<br>materials which have not been wholly obtained<br>there, provided that:</p>
<p>(i) such materials have undergone sufficient<br>working or Processing in that State within<br>the meaning of Article 5, or that</p>
<p>(ii) such materials originate in any of the other<br>States Parties to this Agreement, within the<br>meaning of this Protocol.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 2</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Notwithstanding the provisions of sub-paragraph (b)<br>(ii) of Article 1, products originating in any State Party<br>to this Agreement within the meaning of this Protocol, and<br>exported from one State to another in the same state or<br>having undergone in the exporting State no working or<br>Processing going beyond that referred to in paragraph 5 of<br>Article 5, retain their origin.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purpose of implementing paragraph 1, where<br>products originating in two or more of the States Parties<br>to this Agreement are used and those products have<br>undergone no working or processing in the exporting State<br>going beyond that referred to in paragraph 5 of Article 5,<br>the origin is determined by the product with the highest</p>
<h6>195</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>customs value or, if this is not known and cannot be<br>ascertained, with the highest first ascertainable price<br>paid for the products in that State.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 3</p>
<p>(This protocol does not contain an Article 3)</p>
<p>ARTICLE 4</p>
<p>The following shall be considered as wholly obtained in a<br>State Party to this Agreement within the meaning of sub-<br>paragraph (a) of Article 1:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;mineral products extracted from its soil or from<br>its seabed;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;vegetable products harvested there;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;live animals born and raised there;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;products from live animals raised there;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;products obtained by hunting or fishing conducted<br>there;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;products of sea fishing and other products taken<br>from the sea by its vessels;</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;products made aboard its factory ships<br>exclusively from products referred to in<br>subparagraph (f);</p>
<p>(h) &nbsp;used artides collected there fit only for the<br>recovery of raw materials, subject to Note 5a on<br>used tyres contained in Annex I;</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;waste and scrap resulting from manufacturing<br>operations conducted there;</p>
<p>(j) &nbsp;goods produced there exclusively from products<br>specified in subparagraphs (a) to (i).</p>
<p>ARTICLE 5</p>
<p>1. The expressions &quot;Chapters&quot; and &quot;headings&quot; used in this<br>Protocol shall mean the chapters and the headings (four<br>digit codes) used in the Nomenclature which makes up the<br>&quot;Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System&quot;<br>(hereinafter referred to as the Harmonized System or HS).</p>
<h6>196</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>The expression &quot;classified&quot; shall refer to the<br>classification of a product or material within a particular<br>heading.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purposes of Article 1, non-originating<br>materials are considered to be sufficiently worked or<br>processed when the product obtained is classified within a<br>heading which is different from those within which all the<br>non-originating materials used in its manufacture are<br>classified, subject to the provisions of paragraphs 3, 4<br>and 5.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;For a product mentioned in columns 1 and 2 of the list<br>in Annex II to this Protocol, the conditions set out in<br>column 3 for the product concerned must be fulfilled<br>instead of the rule in paragraph 2.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the products of Chapters 84 to 91 inclusive, as an<br>alternative to satisfying the conditions set out in<br>column 3, the exporter may opt to apply the conditions set<br>out in column 4 instead.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purpose of implementing sub-paragraph (b)&nbsp;(i)</p>
<p>of Article 1, the following shall still be considered as<br>insufficient working or Processing to confer the status of<br>originating product, whether or not there is a change of<br>heading:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Operations to ensure the preservation of<br>merchandise in good condition during transport<br>and storage (ventilation, spreading out, drying,<br>chilling, placing in salt, sulphur dioxide or<br>other aqueous Solutions, removal of damaged<br>parts, and like operations);</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;simple operations consisting of removal of dust,<br>sifting or screening, sorting, classifying,<br>matching (including the making-up of sets of<br>artides) , washing, painting, cutting up:</p>
<p>(c)</p>
<p>(i) changes of packing and breaking up and<br>assembly of consignments;</p>
<p>(ii) simple placing in bottles, fläsks, bags,<br>cases, boxes, fixing on cards or boards,<br>etc., and all other simple packing<br>operations;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;affixing marks, labels or other like<br>distinguishing signs on products or their<br>packaging;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;simple mixing of products, whether or not of<br>different kinds, where one or more components of</p>
<h6>197</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<table border="1">
<tr><td></td><td colspan="2">
<p>the mixtures do not meet the conditions laid down<br>in this Protocol to enable them to be considered<br>as originating products;</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>(f)</p></td><td>
<p>simple assembly of parts of artides to<br>constitute a complete article;</p></td><td></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>(g)</p></td><td>
<p>a combination of two or more operations<br>in subparagraphs (a) to (f);</p></td><td>
<p>specified</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>(h)</p></td><td>
<p>slaughter of animals.</p></td><td></td></tr>
</table>
<p>ARTICLE 6</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The term &quot;value&quot; in the List in Annex II to this<br>Protocol shall mean the customs value at the time of the<br>import of the non-originating materials used or, if this is<br>not known and cannot be ascertained, the first<br>ascertainable price paid for the materials in the territory<br>concerned.</p>
<p>Where the value of the originating material used needs to<br>be established, this paragraph shall be applied mutatis<br>mutandis.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The term &quot;ex-works price&quot; in the List in Annex II<br>shall mean the ex-works price of the product obtained minus<br>any internal taxes which are, or may be, repaid when the<br>product obtained is exported.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 7</p>
<p>Goods originating in a State Party to this Agreement and<br>constituting one single shipment which is not split up may<br>be transported through territory other than that of any<br>State Party to this Agreement with, should the occasion<br>arise, transshipment or temporary warehousing in such<br>territory, provided that the Crossing of the latter<br>territory is justified for geographical reasons, that the<br>goods have remained under the surveillance of the customs<br>authorities in the country of transit or of warehousing,<br>that they have not entered in the commerce of such<br>countries or been delivered for home use there and have not<br>undergone operations other than unloading, reloading or any<br>operation designed to preserve them in good condition.</p>
<h6>198</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>TITLE II</p>
<p>Methods for administrative co-operation</p>
<p>ARTICLE 8</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Originating products within the meaning of this<br>Protocol shall, on import into a State Party to this<br>Agreement benefit from the Agreement upon submission of one<br>of the following documents:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;an EUR.l movement certificate, hereinafter<br>referred to as an &quot;EUR.l certificate&quot; or an EUR.l<br>certificate, valid for a long term, and invoices<br>referring to such certificate made out in<br>accordance with Article 13. A specimen of the<br>EUR.l certificate is given in Annex III to this<br>Protocol;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;an invoice bearing the exporter's declaration as<br>given in Annex IV to this Protocol, made out in<br>accordance with Article 13;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;an invoice bearing the exporter's declaration as<br>given in Annex IV to this Protocol, made out by<br>any exporter for any consignment consisting of<br>one or more packages containing originating<br>products whose total value does not exceed 2,820<br>units of account.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The following originating products within the meaning<br>of this Protocol shall, on importation into a State Party<br>to the Agreement, benefit from the Agreement without it<br>being necessary to produce any of the documents referred to<br>in paragraph 1:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;products sent as small packages from private<br>persons to private persons, provided that the<br>value of the products does not exceed 200 units<br>of account;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;products forming part of travellers' personal<br>luggage, provided that the value of the products<br>does not exceed 565 units of account.</p>
<p>These provisions shall be applied only when such goods<br>are not imported by way of trade and have been declared as<br>meeting the conditions required for the application of the<br>Agreement, and where there is no doubt as to the veracity<br>of such declaration.</p>
<p>Importations which are occasional and consist solely<br>of goods for the personal use of the recipients or</p>
<h6>199</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>travellers or their families shall not be considered as<br>importations by way of trade if it is evident from the<br>nature and quantity of the goods that no commercial purpose<br>is in view.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Amounts in the national currency of the exporting<br>State Party to the Agreement equivalent to the amounts<br>expressed in units of account shall be fixed by the<br>exporting State and communicated to the other States<br>Parties to the Agreement. When the amounts are higher than<br>the corresponding amounts fixed by the importing State,<br>the importing State shall accept them if the goods are<br>invoiced in the currency of the exporting State.</p>
<p>If the goods are invoiced in the currency of another State<br>Party to the Agreement, the importing State shall recognize<br>the amount notified by the State concerned.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;The equivalent of a unit of account in the currencies<br>of the States Parties to the Agreement shall be the amounts<br>specified in Annex VI to this Protocol.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;The amounts expressed in units of account should be<br>reviewed whenever necessary but at least every second year.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;Accessories, spare parts and tools dispatched with a<br>piece of equipment, machine, apparatus or vehicle which are<br>part of the normal equipment and included in the price<br>thereof or are not separately invoiced are regarded as one<br>with the piece of equipment, machine, apparatus or vehicle<br>in question.</p>
<p>7. &nbsp;&nbsp;Sets, within the meaning of General Rule 3 of the<br>Harmonized System, shall be regarded as originating when<br>all component artides are originating products.<br>Nevertheless, when a set is composed of originating and<br>non-originating artides, the set as a whde shall be<br>regarded as originating provided that the value of the non-<br>originating artides does not exceed 15 per cent of the ex-<br>works price of the set.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 9</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;An EUR.l certificate shall be issued by the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State when the goods to which<br>it relätes are exported. It shall be made available to the<br>exporter as soon as actual exportation has been effected or<br>ensured.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The EUR.l certificate shall be issued by the customs<br>authorities of a State Party to this Agreement if the goods<br>to be exported can be considered as products originating in<br>that State within the meaning of Article 1.</p>
<h6>200</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The customs authorities of a State Party to this<br>Agreement may, provided that the goods to be covered by the<br>EUR.l certificates are in its territory, issue EUR.l<br>certificates under the conditions laid down in this<br>Protocol if the goods to be exported can be considered as<br>products originating in a State Party to this Agreement<br>within the meaning of Article 2.</p>
<p>In such cases, the issue of the EUR.l certificates is<br>subject to the presentation of the evidence of origin<br>issued or made out previously.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;An EUR.l certificate may be issued only where it can<br>serve as the documentary evidence required for the purpose<br>of implementing the preferential treatment provided for in<br>this Agreement.</p>
<p>The date of issue of the EUR.l certificate must be<br>indicated in the box on the EUR.l certificate reserved for<br>the customs authorities.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;In exceptional circumstances an EUR.l certificate may<br>also be issued after exportation of the goods to which it<br>relätes if it was not issued at the time of exportation<br>because of errors, involuntary omissions or special<br>circumstances.</p>
<p>The customs authorities may issue an EUR.l certificate<br>retrospectively only after verifying that the particulars<br>supplied in the exporter's application agree with those on<br>the corresponding document.</p>
<p>EUR.l certificates issued retrospectively must be<br>endorsed with one of the following phrases: &quot;ISSUED<br>RETROSPECTIVELY&quot;, &quot;ANNETTU JÄLKIKATEEN, &quot;DELIVRE A<br>POSTERIORI&quot;, &quot;NACHTRÄGLICH AUSGESTELLT&quot;, &quot; ÖTGEFID EFTIR<br>Å&quot;, &quot;RILASCIATO A POSTERIORI&quot;, &quot;UTSTEDT SENERE&quot;, &quot;UTFÄRDAT<br>I EFTERHAND&quot;,</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the event of *he theft, loss or destruction of an<br>EUR.l ce tificate, the exporter may apply to the customs<br>authorities which issued it for a duplicate to be made out<br>on the basis of the export documents in their possession.<br>The duplicate issued in this way must be endorsed with one<br>of the following words: &quot;DUPLICATE&quot;, &quot;KAKSOISKAPPALE&quot;,<br>&quot;DUPLICATA&quot;, &quot;DUPLIKAT&quot;, &quot;EFTIRRIT&quot;, &quot;DUPLICATO&quot;, &quot;pnjm&quot;</p>
<p>The duplicate, which must bear the date of issue of<br>the original EUR.l certificate, shall take effect as from<br>that date.</p>
<p>7. &nbsp;&nbsp;The endorsements referred to in paragraph 5 and 6<br>shall be inserted in the &quot;Remarks&quot; box on the EUR.l<br>certificate.</p>
<h6>201</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>8. &nbsp;&nbsp;It shall always be possible to replace one or nore<br>EUR.l certificates by one or more EUR.l certificates,<br>provided that this is done at the customs Office where the<br>goods are located.</p>
<p>9. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purpose of verifying whether the conditions<br>stated in paragraphs 2 and 3 have been met, the customs<br>authorities shall have the right to call for any<br>documentary evidence or to carry out any check which they<br>consider appropriate.</p>
<p>10. &nbsp;The provisions of paragraph 2 to 9 above shall apply,<br>mutatis mutandis, to the evidence of origin made out by<br>approved exporters under the conditions set out in<br>Article 13.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 10</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;An EUR.l certificate shall be issued only on<br>application having been made in writing by the exporter or,<br>under the exporter's responsibility, by his authorized<br>representative, on the form of which a specimen is given in<br>Annex III to this Protocol, which shall be completed in<br>accordance with this Protocol.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;It shall be the responsibility of the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State to ensure that the form<br>referred to in paragraph 1 is properly completed. In<br>particular, they shall check whether the box reserved for<br>the description of the goods has been completed in such a<br>manner as to exclude any possibility of fraudulent<br>additions. To this end, the description of the goods must<br>be given without leaving any blank lines. Where the box is<br>not completely filled a horizontal line must be drawn below<br>the last line of the description, the empty space being<br>crossed through.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Since the EUR.l certificate constitutes the<br>documentary evidence for the application of the<br>preferentiai tariff and quota arrangements laid down in the<br>Agreement, it shall be the responsibility of the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State to take any steps<br>necessary to verify the origin of the goods and to check<br>the other statements on the certificate.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;When an EUR.l certificate is issued within the meaning<br>of paragraph 5 of Article 9 after goods to which it relätes<br>have actually been exported, the exporter must in the<br>application referred to in paragraph 1:</p>
<p>indicate the place and date of exportation of the<br>goods to which the EUR 1 certificate relätes</p>
<h6>202</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>- certify that no EUR. 1 certificate was issued at<br>the time of exportation of the goods in question<br>and state the reasons.</p>
<p>5. Applications for EUR.l certificates and the evidence<br>of origin referred to in the second sub-paragraph of<br>paragraph 3 of Article 9, upon presentation of which new<br>EUR.l certificates are issued, must be preserved for at<br>least two years by the customs authorities of the exporting<br>State.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 11</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;EUR.l certificates shall be made out on the form of<br>which a specimen is given in Annex III to this Protocol.<br>This form shall be printed in one or more of the official<br>languages of the States Parties to this Agreement or in<br>English. EUR.l certificates shall be made out in one of<br>those languages and in accordance with the provisions of<br>the domestic law of the exporting State; if they are<br>handwritten, they shall be completed in ink in Capital<br>letters.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The EUR.l certificate shall be 210 x 297 millimetres.<br>A tolerance of up to plus 8 millimetres or minus 5<br>millimetres in the length may be allowed. The paper used<br>shall be white-sized writing paper not containing<br>mechanical pulp and weighing not less than 25 grammes per<br>square metre. It shall have a printed green guilloche<br>pattern background making any falsification by mechanical<br>or Chemical means apparent to the eye.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The States Parties to this Agreement may reserve the<br>right to print the EUR.l certificates themselves or may<br>have them printed by printers approved by them. In the<br>latter case, each EUR.l certificate must include a<br>reference to such approval. Each EUR.l certificate must<br>bear the name and address of the printer or a mark by which<br>the printer can be identified. It sha”. also bear a serial<br>number, whether c. not printed,.by which it can be<br>identified.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 12</p>
<p>1. An EUR. 1 certificate must be submitted, within four<br>months of the date of issue by the customs authorities of<br>the exporting State, to the customs authorities of the<br>importing State where the goods are entered, in accordance<br>with the procedures laid down by that State. The said<br>authorities may require a translation of a certificate.<br>They may also require the import declaration to be<br>accompanied by a statement from the importer to the effect</p>
<h6>203</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>that the goods meet the conditions required for the<br>implementation of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Without prejudice to paragraph 5 of Article 5, where,<br>at the requestof the person declaring the goods at<br>customs, a dismantled or non-assembled article falling<br>within Chapter 84 or 85 of the Harmonized System is<br>imported by instalments under the conditions laid down by<br>the competent authorities, it shall be considered to be a<br>single article and an EUR.l certificate may be submitted<br>for the whole article upon importation of the first<br>instalment.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;An EUR.l certificate which is submitted to the customs<br>authorities of the importing State after the final date for<br>presentation specified in paragraph 1 may be accepted for<br>the purpose of applying preferential treatment, where the<br>failure to submit the certificate by the final date set is<br>due to force majeure or exceptional circumstances.</p>
<p>In other cases of belated presentation, the customs<br>authorities of the importing State may accept the EUR.l<br>certificates where the goods have been submitted to them<br>before the said final date.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;The discovery of slight discrepancies between the<br>statements made in the EUR.l certificate and those made in<br>the documents submitted to the customs Office for the<br>purpose of carrying out the formalities for importing the<br>goods shall not ipso facto render the certificate null and<br>void, provided it is duly established that the certificate<br>corresponds to the goods.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;EUR.l certificates shall be preserved by the customs<br>authorities of the importing State in accordance with the<br>rules in force in that State.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;Proof that the conditions set out in Article 7 have<br>been met shall be provided by submission to the customs<br>authorities of the importing State of either:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;a single supporting transport document, made out<br>in the exporting State, under the cover of which<br>the transit country has been crossed; or:</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;a certificate issued by the customs authorities<br>of the transit country containing:</p>
<p>- an exact description of the goods,</p>
<p>the date of unloading and reloading of the<br>goods and, where applicable, the names of<br>the ships,</p>
<h6>204</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>- certified proof of the conditions under<br>which the goods have stayed in the transit<br>country;</p>
<p>(c) or, failing these, any substantiating documents.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 13</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Notwithstanding paragrahps 1 to 7 of Article 9 and<br>paragraphs 1, 4, and 5 of Article 10, a simplified<br>procedure for the issue of the documentation relating to<br>the evidence of origin shall be applicable under the terms<br>of the provisions set out below.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The customs authorities in the exporting State may<br>authorize an exporter, hereinafter referred to as &quot;approved<br>exporter&quot;, who makes frequent shipments for which EUR.l<br>certificates may be issued, and who offers to the<br>satisfaction of the customs authorities all guarantees<br>necessary to verify the originating status of the goods,<br>not to submit to the customs Office in the exporting State<br>at the time of export either the goods or the application<br>for an EUR.l certificate relating to those goods, for the<br>purpose of obtaining an EUR.l certificate under the<br>conditions laid down in paragraphs 1 to 4 of Article 9.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the customs authorities may authorize an<br>approved exporter to draw up EUR.l certificates, valid for<br>a maximum period of one year from the date of issue,<br>hereinafter referred to as &quot;LT certificates&quot;. The<br>authorization shall be granted only where the originating<br>status of the goods to be exported is expected to remain<br>unchanged for the period of validity of the LT certificate.<br>If any goods are no longer covered by the LT certificate,<br>the approved exporter shall immediately inform the customs<br>authorities who gave the authorization.</p>
<p>Where the simplified procedure applies, the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State may prescribe the use of<br>EUR.l certificates bearing a distinctive sign by which they<br>may be identified.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;The authorization referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3<br>shall stipulate, at the choice of customs authorities, that<br>Box 11, &quot;Customs endorsement&quot;, of the EUR.l certificate<br>must:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;either be endorsed beforehand with the stamp of<br>the competent customs Office of the exporting<br>State and the handwritten or non-handwritten<br>signature of an official of that Office; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;be endorsed by the approved exporter with a<br>special stamp which has been approved by the</p>
<h6>205</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>customs authorities of the exporting State and<br>corresponds to the specimen given in Annex V to<br>this Protocol; this stamp may be preprinted on<br>the form.</p>
<p>Box 11, &quot;Customs endorsement&quot;, of the EUR.l certificate<br>shall be completed if necessary by the approved exporter.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the cases referred to in paragraph 4 (a), one of<br>the following phrases shall be entered in Box 7, &quot;Remarks&quot;,<br>of the EUR.l certificate: &quot;Simplified procedure&quot;,<br>&quot;Yksinkertaistettu menettely&quot;, &quot;Procédure simplifiée&quot;,<br>&quot;Vereinfachtes Verfähren&quot;, &quot;Einföldud afgreidsla&quot;,<br>&quot;Procedura semplificata&quot;, &quot;Forenklet prosedyre&quot;, &quot;Förenklad<br>procedur&quot;, &quot;vvoio i»5nn&quot;. The approved exporter shall if<br>necessary indicate in Box 13, &quot;Request for verification&quot;,<br>the name and address of the customs authority competent to<br>verify the EUR.l certificate.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the case referred to in paragraph 3, the approved<br>exporter shall also enter in box 7 of the EUR.l certificate<br>one of the following phrases:</p>
<p>&quot;LT certificate valid until<br>&quot;LT-todistus voimassa ... saakka&quot;,<br>&quot;certificat LT valable jusqu'au ...&quot;,<br>&quot;LT-Certificat gultig bis ...&quot;,<br>&quot;LT-skirteini gildir til ...&quot;,<br>&quot;certificato LT valido fino a ...&quot;,<br>&quot;LT-sertifikat gyldig til —&quot;,<br>&quot;LT-certifikat giltigt till ...&quot;,<br>&quot;_____ t» ipma miynn &quot;</p>
<p>(date indicated in numerals),</p>
<p>and a reference to the authorization under which the<br>relevant LT certificate has been issued.</p>
<p>The approved exporter shall not be required to refer in Box<br>8 and Box 9 of the LT certificate to the marks and numbers<br>and number and kind of packages and the gross weight (kg)<br>or other measures (litres, m3, etc.). Box 8 must, however,<br>contain a description and designation of the goods which is<br>sufficiently precise to allow for their Identification.</p>
<p>7. &nbsp;&nbsp;Notwithstanding paragraphs 1 and 3 of Article 12, the<br>LT certificate must be submitted to the customs Office of<br>import at or before the first importation of any goods to<br>which it relätes. When the importer carries out the<br>customs clearance at several customs offices in the State<br>of importation, the customs authorities may request him to<br>produce a copy of the LT certificate to all of those<br>offices.</p>
<h6>206</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>8. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where an LT certificate has been submitted to the<br>customs authorities, the evidence of the originating status<br>of the imported goods shall, during the validity of the LT<br>certificate, be given by invoices which satisfy the<br>following conditions:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;when an invoice includes both goods originating<br>in a State Party to this Agreement and non-<br>originating goods, the exporter shall distinguish<br>clearly between these two categories;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;the exporter shall state on each invoice the<br>number of the LT certificate which covers the<br>goods and the date of expiry of the certificate<br>and the name(s) of the country or countries in<br>which the goods originate.</p>
<p>The statement on the invoice made by the exporter<br>of the number of the LT certificate with the<br>indication of the country of origin shall<br>constitute a declaration that the goods fulfil<br>the conditions laid down in this Protocol for the<br>acquisition of preferential origin status in<br>trade between the States Parties to this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>The customs authorities of the exporting State<br>may require that the entries, which, under the<br>above provisions, must appear on the invoice, be<br>supported by the manuscript signature followed by<br>the name of the signatory in clear script;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the description and the designation of the goods<br>on the invoice shall be in sufficient detail to<br>show clearly that the goods are also listed on<br>the LT certificate to which the invoice refers;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;the invoices can be made out only for the goods<br>exported during the period of validity of the<br>relevant LT certificate. They may however be<br>produced at the import customs Office within four<br>months of the date of their being made out by the<br>exporter.</p>
<p>9. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the framework of the simplified procedures,<br>invoices which satisfy the conditions of this Article may<br>be made out and/or transmitted using telecommunications or<br>electronic data Processing methods. Such invoices shall be<br>accepted by the customs of the importing State as evidence<br>of the originating status of the goods imported in<br>accordance with the procedures laid down by the customs<br>authorities there.</p>
<h6>207</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>10. &nbsp;Should the customs authorities of the exporting State<br>identify that a certificate and/or invoice issued under the<br>provisions of this Article is invalid in relation to any<br>goods supplied, they shall immediately notify the customs<br>authorities of the importing State of the facts.</p>
<p>11. &nbsp;The customs authorities may authorize an approved<br>exporter to make out invoices bearing the declaration given<br>in Annex IV to this Protocol in place of EUR.1<br>certificates.</p>
<p>The declaration made by the approved exporter on the<br>invoice shall be made out in one of the official languages<br>of the States Parties to this Agreement or in English. It<br>shall be signed in manuscript and must either:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;have a reference to the approved exporter's<br>authorization number, or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;be endorsed by the approved exporter with the<br>special stamp referred to in paragraph 4 (b)<br>which has been approved by the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State. This stamp<br>may be preprinted on the invoice.</p>
<p>12. &nbsp;However, the customs authorities in the exporting<br>State may authorize an approved exporter not to sign the<br>statement in paragraph 8 (b) or the declaration referred to<br>in paragraph 11 given on the invoice, when such invoices<br>are made out and/or transmitted using telecommunications or<br>electronic data Processing methods.</p>
<p>The said customs authorities shall lay down conditions for<br>the implementation of this paragraph, including, if they so<br>require, a written undertaking from the approved exporter,<br>that he accepts full responsibility for such statement and<br>declaration as if they had in fact been signed in<br>manuscript by him.</p>
<p>13. &nbsp;In the authorizations referred to in paragraphs 2, 3<br>and 11 the customs authorities shall ^pecify in particular:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the conditions under which the applications for<br>FJR.l certificates or for LT certificates are<br>made or under which the declaration concerning<br>the origin of the goods is made on the invoice;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;the conditions under which these applications, as<br>well as a copy of the invoices referring to an LT<br>certificate and of the invoices bearing the<br>exporter's declaration, are kept for at least two<br>years. In the case of LT certificates or<br>invoices referring to an LT certificate, this<br>period shall begin from the date of expiry of<br>validity of the LT certificate. These provisions</p>
<h6>208</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>shall also apply to the EUR.l certificates or LT<br>certificates and the invoices referring to an LT<br>certificate, as well as to invoices bearing the<br>exporter's declaration, having served as the<br>basis for the issue of other evidence of origin,<br>used under the conditions laid down in the second<br>sub-paragraph of paragraph 3 of Article 9.</p>
<p>14. &nbsp;The customs authorities in the exporting State may<br>declare certain categories of goods ineligible for the<br>special treatment provided for in paragraphs 2, 3 and 11.</p>
<p>15. &nbsp;The customs authorities shall refuse the<br>authorizations referred to in paragraphs 2, 3 and 11 to<br>exporters who do not offer all the guarantees which they<br>consider necessary.</p>
<p>The customs authorities may withdraw the authorizations at<br>any time. They must do so where the conditions of approval<br>are no longer satisfied or the approved exporter no longer<br>offers those guarantees.</p>
<p>16. &nbsp;The approved exporter may be required to inform the<br>customs authorities, in accordance with the rules which<br>they lay down, of goods to be dispatched by him, so that<br>the competent customs Office may make any verification it<br>thinks necessary before the dispatch of the goods.</p>
<p>17. &nbsp;The provisions of this Article shall not prejudice<br>application of the rules of the States Parties to this<br>Agreement on customs formalities and the use of customs<br>documents.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 14</p>
<p>The declaration referred to in paragraph 1 (c) of Article 8<br>shall be made out by the exporter in the form given in<br>Annex IV to this Protocol in one of the official languages<br>of the States Parties to this Agreement or in English. It<br>shall be typed or stamped and signed by ha..J. The<br>exporter must keep a copy of the invoice bearing the said<br>declaration for at least two years.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 15</p>
<p>1. The exporter or his representative shall submit with<br>his request for an EUR.l certificate any appropriate<br>supporting document proving that the goods to be exported<br>qualify for the issue of an EUR.l certificate.</p>
<p>He shall undertake to submit at the request of the<br>appropriate authorities, any supplementary evidence they<br>may require for the purpose of establishing the correctness</p>
<h6>209</h6>
<p>14 Riksdagen 1992193. 1 saml. Nr 22. Del 1</p>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>of the originating status of the goods eligible for<br>preferential treatment and shall undertake to agree to any<br>inspection of his accounts and to any check on the<br>processes of the obtaining of the above goods, carried out<br>by the said authorities.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Exporters must keep for at least two years the<br>supporting documents referred to in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 shall apply<br>mutatis mutandis in the case of the use of the procedures<br>laid down in paragraphs 2 and 3 of Article 13 and of the<br>declarations referred to in paragraphs 1 (b) and 1 (c) of<br>Article 8.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 16</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Goods sent from an EFTA State or from Israel for<br>exhibition in a country other than a State Party to this<br>Agreement and sold after the exhibition for importation<br>into Israel or into an EFTA State shall benefit on<br>importation from the provisions of this Agreement on<br>condition that the goods meet the requirements of this<br>Protocol entitling them to be recognized as originating in<br>an EFTA State or in Israel and provided that it is shown to<br>the satisfaction of the Customs authorities that:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;an exporter has consigned these goods from an<br>EFTA State or from Israel to the country in which<br>the exhibition is held and has exhibited them<br>there;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;the goods have been sold or otherwise disposed of<br>by that exporter to someone in Israel or in an<br>EFTA State;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the goods have been consigned during the<br>exhibition or immediately thereafter to Israel or<br>to «n EFTA State in the state in which they were<br>sent for exhibition;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;the goods have not, since they were consigned for<br>exhibition, been used for any purpose other than<br>demonstration at the exhibition.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;An EUR.l certificate must be produced to the customs<br>authorities in the normal manner. The name and address of<br>the exhibition must be indicated thereon. Where necessary,<br>additional documentary evidence of the nature of the goods<br>and the conditions under which they have been exhibited may<br>be required.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Paragraph 1 shall apply to any trade, industrial,<br>agricultural or crafts exhibition, fair or similar public</p>
<h6>210</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>show or display which is not organized for private purposes<br>in shops or business premises with a view to the sale of<br>foreign goods, and during which the goods remain under<br>customs control.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 17</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;In order to ensure the proper application of this<br>Title, the States Parties to this Agreement shall assist<br>each other through their respective customs<br>administrations, in checking the authenticity and accuracy<br>of EUR.l certificates, including those issued under<br>paragraph 3 of Article 9 and the exporters' declarations<br>made on invoices.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The Joint Committee shall be authorized to take any<br>decisions necessary for the methods of administrative co-<br>operation to be applied in due time in the States Parties<br>to this Agreement.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The customs authorities of the States Parties to this<br>Agreement shall provide each other, through the EFTA<br>Secretariat, with specimen impressions of stamps used in<br>their customs offices for the issue of EUR.l certificates.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;Penalties shall be imposed on any person who draws up,<br>or causes to be drawn up, a document which contains<br>incorrect particulars for the purpose of obtaining a<br>preferential treatment for goods.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;The States Parties to this Agreement shall take all<br>necessary steps to ensure that goods traded under cover of<br>an EUR.l certificate, which in the course of transport use<br>a free zone situated in their territory, are not<br>substituted by other goods and that they do not undergo<br>handling other than normal operations designed to prevent<br>their deterioration.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;When products originating in a State Party to this<br>Agreement and imported into a free zone under cover of an<br>EUR.l certificate undergo treatment or Processing, the<br>customs authorities concerned must issue a new EUR.l<br>certificate at the exporter's request if the treatment or<br>Processing undergone is in conformity with the provisions<br>of this Protocol.</p>
<h6>211</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>ARTICLE 18</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent verifications of EUR.l certificates and of<br>exporters' declarations made on invoices shall be carried<br>out at random or whenever the customs authorities of the<br>importing State have reasonable doubt as to the<br>authenticity of the document or the accuracy of the<br>information regarding the true origin of the goods in<br>question.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purposes of implementing the provisions of<br>paragraph 1, the customs authorities of the importing State<br>shall return the EUR.l certificate and the invoice, if it<br>has been submitted, or the invoice referring to an LT<br>certificate, or the invoice bearing the exporter's<br>declaration or a copy of those documents, to the customs<br>authorities of the exporting State, giving where<br>appropriate, the reasons of substance or form for an<br>inquiry.</p>
<p>The customs authorities shall forward, in support of the<br>request for a postexiori verification, any documents and<br>information that have been obtained suggesting that the<br>particulars given on the EUR.l certificate or the invoice<br>are inaccurate.</p>
<p>If the customs authorities of the importing State decide to<br>suspend the provisions of the Agreement while awaiting the<br>results of the verification, they shall offer to release<br>the goods to the importer subject to any precautionary<br>measures judged necessary.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The customs authorities of the importing State shall<br>be informed of the results of the verification as soon as<br>possible. These results must be such as to make it<br>possible to determine whether the documents returned under<br>paragraph 2 apply to the goods actually exported, and<br>whether these goods can, in fact, qualify for application<br>of the preferential arrangement</p>
<p>Where such disputes cannot be settled between the customs<br>authorities of the importing State and those of the<br>exporting State or where they raise a question as to the<br>interpretation of this Protocol they shall be submitted to<br>the Sub-Committee on customs and origin matters referred to<br>in Article 26. The decisions shall be taken by the Joint<br>Committee.</p>
<p>For the purpose of the subsequent verification of EUR.l<br>certificates, the customs authorities of the exporting<br>State must keep the export documents, or copies of EUR.l<br>certificates used in place thereof, for at least two years.</p>
<h6>212</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>TITLE III</p>
<p>Final provisions</p>
<p>ARTICLE 19</p>
<p>The States Parties to this Agreement shall each take the<br>steps necessary to implement this Protocol.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 20</p>
<p>The Annexes to this Protocol shall form an integral part<br>thereof.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 21</p>
<p>Goods which conform to the provisions of Title I and which<br>on the date of entry into force of the Agreement are either<br>being transported or are being held in a State Party to<br>this Agreement in temporary storage, in bonded warehouses<br>or in free zones, may be accepted as originating products<br>subject to the submission, within four months from that<br>date, to the customs authorities of the importing State of<br>evidence of origin, drawn up retrospectively, and of any<br>documents that provide supporting evidence of the<br>conditions of transport.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 22</p>
<p>The States Parties to this Agreement undertake to<br>introduce measures necessary to ensure that the EUR.l<br>certificates which their customs authorities are authorized<br>to issue in pursuance of this Agreement are issued under<br>the conditions laid down by this Agreement. They also<br>undertake to provide the administrative co-operation<br>necessary for this pu^nose, in particular to check on the<br>itinerary of goods traded under this Agreement and the<br>places in which they have been held.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 23</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to the provisions of Protocol A,<br>products which are of the kind to which the Agreement<br>applies, and which are used in the manufacture of products<br>for which an EUR.l certificate, an LT certificate or the<br>invoices referring to the LT certificate, or an invoice<br>bearing the exporter's declaration are issued or completed,<br>can only be the subject of drawback of customs duty or</p>
<h6>213</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>benefit from an exemption of customs duty of whatever kind<br>when products originating in a State Party to this<br>Agreement are concerned.</p>
<p>2. In this Article, the term &quot;customs duty&quot; also means<br>charges having an effect equivalent to customs duty</p>
<p>ARTICLE 24</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;Where, by virtue of this Agreement, imports into an<br>EFTA State are to be treated differently from imports<br>covered by the EFTA Convention, the treatment provided for<br>by this Agreement shall be applied to all products which<br>are accompanied by evidence of origin referred to in<br>paragraph 1 of Article 8, issued or made out in Israel, or<br>by any such evidence of origin issued in an EFTA State and<br>bearing the expression &quot;EFTA-Israel Trade&quot;.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;An exporter in an EFTA State or his representative<br>shall enter the expression &quot;EFTA-Israel Trade&quot; on the<br>evidence of origin in trade between EFTA States in cases<br>where products have obtained their originating status by<br>virtue of this Agreement by use of materials originating in<br>Israel.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 1, products<br>originating in an EFTA State which are re-exported from<br>Israel, shall benefit at import into an EFTA State from<br>treatment equal to that which they would have received had<br>they been sent directly from one EFTA State to another.</p>
<p>The products must be in the same state or have undergone no<br>working or Processing in Israel going beyond that referred<br>to in paragraph 5 of Article 5. This treatment will be<br>granted only upon submission to the customs authorities of<br>the importing EFTA State of an EUR.l certificate, issued by<br>the appropriate customs Office in Israel, in which the<br>expression &quot;Application Article 24.3&quot; has been inserted and<br>authenticated by the stamp of the said Office.</p>
<p>ARTICLES 25</p>
<p>(This Protocol does not contain an Article 25)</p>
<p>ARTICLE 26</p>
<p>A Sub-Committee on customs and origin matters shall be set<br>up under the Joint Committee in accordance with paragraph 5<br>of Article 26 of the Agreement to assist it in carrying out<br>its duties and to ensure a continuous information and<br>consultation process between experts.</p>
<h6>214</h6>
<p>It shall be composed of experts tron the States Parties to<br>the Agreement responsible for questions related to origin<br>rules.</p>
<p>ARTICLE 27</p>
<p>For the purpose of implementing sub-paragraph (b) (ii) of<br>Article 1 any product originating in a State Party to this<br>Agreement shall, on exportation to another State Party to<br>this Agreement, be treated as a non-originating product<br>during the period t&gt;r periods in which the last-mentioned<br>State Party to this Agreement applies the rate of duty<br>applicable to third countries or any corresponding<br>safeguard measure to such products in accordance with this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>
<p>215</p>
<p>ANNEX I</p>
<p>EXPLANATORY NOTES</p>
<p>Note 1 - Article 1</p>
<p>The term &quot;State Party to this Agreement&quot; shall also<br>cover the territorial waters of this State.</p>
<p>Vessels operating on the high seas, including factory<br>ships, on which the fish caught is worked or processed<br>shall be considered as part of the territory of the State<br>Party to this Agreement to which they belong provided that<br>they satisfy the conditions set out in Explanatory Note 4.</p>
<p>Note 2 - Artides 1, 2 and 4</p>
<p>The conditions set out in Article 1 relative to the<br>acquisition of originating status must be fulfilled without<br>interruption in a State Party to this Agreement except as<br>provided for in Article 2.</p>
<p>If originating products exported from a State Party to<br>this Agreement to another country are returned, except as<br>provided for in Article 2, they must be considered as non-<br>originating unless it can be demonstrated to the<br>satisfaction of the customs authorities that:</p>
<p>the goods returned are the same goods as those<br>exported, and</p>
<p>they have not undergone any operations beyond<br>that necessary to preserve them in good condition<br>while in that country.</p>
<p>Note 3 - Artides 1 and 2</p>
<p>In order to determine whether goods are originating<br>products it shall not be necessary to establish whether the<br>power and fuel, plant and equipment, and machines and tools<br>used to obtain such goods originate in third countries or<br>not.</p>
<p>Note 4 - sub-paragraph (f) of Article 4</p>
<p>The term &quot;its vessels&quot; shall apply only to vessels:</p>
<p>(a) which are registered or recorded in a State Party<br>to this Agreement;</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>Annex I to</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>
<p>216</p>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Annex I to</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>(b) &nbsp;which sail under the flag of a State Party to<br>this Agreement;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;which are at least 50 per cent owned by nationals<br>of a State Party to this Agreement or by a<br>company with its head Office in such a State, of<br>which the manager or managers, chainnan of the<br>board of directors or of the supervisory board,<br>and the majority of the members of such boards<br>are nationals of a State Party to this Agreement<br>and of which, in addition, in the case of<br>partnerships or limited companies, at least half<br>of the Capital belongs to such a State or to<br>public bodies or nationals of such a State;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;of which the captain and officers are all<br>nationals of a State Party to this Agreement;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;of which at least 75 per cent of the crew are<br>nationals of a State Party to this Agreement.</p>
<p>Note 5 - Artides 4 and 5</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The unit of qualification for the application of the<br>origin rules shall be the particular product which is<br>considered as the basic unit when determining</p>
<p>classification using the Nomenclature of the Harmonized<br>System. In the case of sets of products which are<br>classified by virtue of General Rule 3, the unit of<br>qualification shall be determined in respect of each item<br>in the set; this also applies to the sets of heading Nos<br>6308, 8206 and 9605.</p>
<p>Accordingly, it follows that:</p>
<p>- when a product composed of a group or assembly of<br>artides is classified under the terms of the<br>Harmonized System within a single heading, the<br>whole constitutes the unit of qualification,</p>
<p>when a consignment consists of a number of<br>identical products classified within the same<br>heading of the harmonized system, each product<br>must be taken individually when applying the<br>origin rules.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where, under General Rule 5 of the Harmonized System,<br>packing is included with the product for classification<br>purposes, it shall be included for purposes of determining<br>origin.</p>
<p>Note 5a - sub-paragraph (h) of Article 4</p>
<h6>217</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22<br>Annex I to<br>Protocol B</h6>
<p>In the case of used tyres, the term &quot;used artides<br>collected there , fit only for the recovery of raw<br>materials&quot; does not only cover used tyres fit only for the<br>recovery of raw materials but also used tyres fit only for<br>retreading or for use as waste.</p>
<p>Note 6 - Paragraph 2 of Article 5</p>
<p>The Introductory Notes to Annex II shall also apply<br>where appropriate to all products manufactured using non-<br>originating materials even if they are not subject to a<br>specific condition contained in the List in Annex II but<br>are subject instead to the change of heading rule set out<br>in paragraph 2 of Article 5.</p>
<p>Note 7 - Article 6</p>
<p>&quot;Ex-works price&quot; shall mean the price paid to the<br>manufacturer in whose undertaking the last working or<br>Processing is carried out, provided the price includes the<br>value of all the products used in manufacture.</p>
<p>&quot;Customs value&quot; shall be understood as meaning the<br>customs value as determined in accordance with the<br>Agreement on implementation of Article VII of the General<br>Agreement on Tariffs and Trade done at Geneva on 12 April<br>1979.</p>
<p>Note 8 - Paragraph 1 of Article 8</p>
<p>The facility of using, under this Protocol, the<br>invoice as evidence of the originating status of the goods,<br>shall be extended to the delivery note or any other<br>commercial document which describes the goods concerned in<br>sufficient detail to enable them to be identified.</p>
<p>In the case of products sent by post which, within the<br>meaning of paragraph 2 of Article 8, are not considered as<br>importations by way of trade, the declaration of the<br>originating status can also be made on the customs<br>declaration C2/CP3 or on a sheet of paper annexed to that<br>declaration.</p>
<p>Note 9 - Paragraph 1 of Article 17 and Article 22</p>
<p>Where an EUR.l certificate has been issued under the<br>conditions laid down in Article 9 (3) and relätes to goods<br>re-exported in the same state, the customs authorities of<br>the country of destination must be able to obtain, by means<br>of administrative co-operation, true copies of the evidence<br>of origin issued or made out previously relating to those<br>goods.</p>
<h6>218</h6>
<p>Note 10 - Article 23</p>
<p>&quot;Drawback of customs duty or exemption from customs<br>duty of whatever kind&quot; shall mean any arrangement for<br>refund or remission, partial or complete, of customs duties<br>applicable to products used in manufacture, provided that<br>the said provision concedes, expressly or in effect, this<br>repayment or non-charging or the non-imposition when goods<br>obtained from the said products are exported but not when<br>they are retained for home use.</p>
<p>&quot;Products used in manufacture&quot; shall mean any products<br>in respect of which a &quot;drawback of customs duty or<br>exemption from customs duty of whatever kind&quot; is requested<br>as a result of the export of originating products for which<br>an EUR.l certificate, an LT certificate or the invoices<br>referring to the LT certificate, or an invoice bearing the<br>exporter's declaration are issued or made out.</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>Annex I to</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>
<p>219</p>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22<br>Annex II to<br>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>ANNEX II</p>
<p>List of working or Processing required to be carried out on<br>non-originating materials in order that the product<br>manufactured can obtain originating status</p>
<p>INTRODUCTORY NOTES</p>
<p>General</p>
<p>Note 1</p>
<p>1.1 &nbsp;The first two columns in the List describe the<br>products obtained. The first column gives the<br>heading number, or the Chapter number, used in<br>the Harmonized System and the second column gives<br>the description of goods used in that System for<br>that heading or Chapter. For each entry in the<br>first two columns a rule is specified in columns<br>3 and 4. Where, in some cases, the entry in the<br>first column is preceded by an &quot;ex&quot;, this<br>signifies that the rule in column 3 or column 4<br>only applies to the part of that heading or<br>Chapter as described in column 2.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;Where several heading numbers are grouped<br>together in column 1 or a Chapter number is given<br>and the description of product in column 2 is<br>therefore given in general terms, the adjacent<br>rule in column 3 or column 4 applies to all<br>products which, under the Harmonized System, are<br>classified within headings of the Chapter or<br>within any of the headings grouped together in<br>column 1.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;Where there are different rules in the List<br>applying to different products within a heading,<br>each indent contains the description of that part<br>of the heading covered by the adjacent rule in<br>column 3 or column 4.</p>
<p>1.4 &nbsp;For the products of Chapters 84 to 91 inclusive,<br>if no origin rule is given in column 4, the rule<br>set out in column 3 has to be applied.</p>
<p>Note 2</p>
<p>2.1 The term &quot;manufacture&quot; covers any kind of working<br>or Processing including &quot;assembly&quot; or specific<br>operations. However, see paragraph 5 of Note 3<br>below.</p>
<h6>220</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Annex II to</h6>
<h6>ProtocolB</h6>
<p>2.2 &nbsp;The term &quot;material&quot; covers any &quot;ingredient&quot;, &quot;raw<br>material&quot;, &quot;component&quot; or &quot;part&quot;, etc., used in<br>the manufacture of the product.</p>
<p>2.3 &nbsp;The term &quot;product&quot; refers to the product being<br>manufactured, even if it is intended for later<br>use in another manufacturing operation.</p>
<p>Note 3</p>
<p>3.1 &nbsp;In the case of any heading not in the List or any<br>part of a heading that is not in the List, the<br>&quot;change of heading&quot; rule set out in paragraph 2<br>of Article 5 applies. If a &quot;change of heading&quot;<br>condition applies to any entry in the List, then<br>it is contained in the rule in column 3.</p>
<p>3.2 &nbsp;The working or Processing required by a rule in<br>column 3 or column 4 has to be carried out only<br>in relation to the non-originating materials<br>used. The restrictions contained in a rule in<br>column 3 or column 4 likewise apply only to the<br>non-originating materials used.</p>
<p>3.3 &nbsp;Where a rule States that &quot;materials of any<br>heading&quot; may be used, materials of the same<br>heading as the product may also be used, subject,<br>however, to any specific limitations which may<br>also be contained in the rule. However, the<br>expression &quot;manufacture from materials of any<br>heading including other materials of heading<br>No...&quot; means that only materials classified<br>within the same heading as the product of a<br>different description than that of the product as<br>given in column 2 of the List may be used.</p>
<p>3.4 &nbsp;If a product, made from non-originating materials<br>which has acquired originating status during<br>manufacture by virtue of the change of heading<br>rule or its own List rule, is used as a material<br>in the process of manufacture of another product,<br>then the rule applicable to the product in which<br>it is incorporated does not apply to it.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>An engine of heading No. 8407, for which the<br>rule States that the value of the non-<br>originating materials which may be<br>incorporated may not exceed 40 % of the ex-<br>works price, is made from &quot;other alloy Steel<br>roughly shaped by forging&quot; of heading No.<br>7224.</p>
<h6>221</h6>
<p>If this forging has been forged in the<br>country concerned from a non-originating<br>ingot then the forging has already acquired<br>origin by virtue of the rule for heading No.<br>ex 7224 in the List. It can then count as<br>originating in the value calculation for the<br>engine regardless of whether it was produced<br>in the same factory or another. The value<br>of the non-originating ingot is thus not<br>taken into account when adding up the value<br>of the non-originating materials used.</p>
<p>3.5 Even if the change of heading rule or the rule<br>contained in the List are satisfied, a product<br>does not have origin if the Processing carried<br>out, taken as a whole, is insufficient in the<br>sense of paragraph 5 of Article 5.</p>
<p>Note 4</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;The rule in the List represents the minimum<br>amount of working or Processing required and the<br>carrying out of more working or Processing also<br>confers originating status; conversely, the<br>carrying out of less working or Processing cannot<br>confer origin. Thus if a rule says that non-<br>originating material at a certain level of<br>manufacture may be used, the use of such material<br>at an earlier stage of manufacture is allowed and<br>the use of such material at later stage is not.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;When a rule in the List specifies that a product<br>may be manufactured from more than one material,<br>this means that any one or more of the materials<br>may be used. It does not require that all be<br>used.</p>
<p>- For example:</p>
<p>The rule for fabrics says that natural<br>fibres may be used and that Chemical<br>materials, among other materials, may also<br>be used. This does not mean that both have<br>to be used, one can use one or the other or<br>both.</p>
<p>If, however, a restriction applies to one<br>material and other restrictions apply to other<br>materials in the same rule, then the restrictions<br>only apply to the materials actually used.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>The rule for sewing machines specifies that<br>the thread tension mechanism used has to<br>originate and that the zigzag mechanism used</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>Annex II to</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>
<p>222</p>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Annex II to</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>also has to originate; these two<br>restrictions only apply if the mechanisms<br>concerned are actually incorporated into the<br>sewing machine.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;When a rule in the List specifies that a product<br>must be manufactured from a particular material,<br>the condition obviously does not prevent the use<br>of other materials which, because of their<br>inherent nature, cannot satisfy the rule.</p>
<p>- For example:</p>
<p>The rule for heading No. 1904 which<br>specifically excludes the use of cereals or<br>their derivatives does not prevent the use<br>of mineral salts, Chemicals and other<br>additives which are not produced from<br>cereals.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>In the case of an article made from non-<br>woven materials, if the use of only non-<br>originating yarn is allowed for this class<br>of article, it is not possible to start from<br>non-woven cloth - even if non-wovens cannot<br>normally be made from yarn. In such cases,<br>the starting material would normally be at<br>the stage before yarn - that is the fibre<br>stage.</p>
<p>See also paragraph 3 of Note 7 in relation to<br>textiles.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;If in a rule in the List two or more percentages<br>are given for the maximum value of non-<br>originating materials that can be used, then<br>these percentages may not be added together. The<br>maximum value of all the non-originating<br>materials used may never exceed the highest of<br>the percentages given. Furthermore the<br>individual percentages must not be exceeded in<br>relation to the particular materials they apply<br>to.</p>
<p>Textiles</p>
<p>Note 5</p>
<p>5.1 The term &quot;natural fibres&quot; is used in the List to<br>refer to fibres other than artificial or<br>synthetic fibres and is restricted to the stages<br>before spinning takes place, including waste and<br>unless otherwise specified, the term &quot;natural</p>
<h6>223</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22<br>Annex II to<br>Protocol B</h6>
<p>fibres&quot; includes fibres that have been carded,<br>combed or otherwise processed but not spun.</p>
<p>5.2 &nbsp;The term &quot;natural fibres&quot; includes horsehair of<br>heading No. 0503, silk of headings Nos. 5002 and<br>5003 as well as the wool fibres, fine or coarse<br>animal hair of headings Nos. 5101 to 5105, the<br>cotton fibres of headings Nos. 5201 to 5203 and<br>the other vegetable fibres of headings Nos. 5301<br>to 5305.</p>
<p>5.3 &nbsp;The terms &quot;textile pulp&quot;, &quot;Chemical materials&quot;<br>and &quot;paper-making materials&quot; are used in the List<br>to describe the materials not classified within<br>Chapters 50 to 63 which can be used to<br>manufacture artificial, synthetic or paper fibres<br>or yarns.</p>
<p>5.4 &nbsp;The term &quot;man-made staple fibres&quot; is used in the<br>List to refer to synthetic or artificial filament<br>tow, staple fibres or waste, of headings Nos.<br>5501 to 5507.</p>
<p>Note 6</p>
<p>6.1 &nbsp;In the case of the products classified within<br>those headings in the List where a reference is<br>made to this Introductory Note, the conditions<br>set out in column 3 of the List shall not be<br>applied to any basic textile materials used in<br>their manufacture which, taken together,<br>represent 10 % or less of the total weight of all<br>the basic textile materials used (but see also<br>paragraphs 3 and 4 of Note 6 below).</p>
<p>6.2 &nbsp;However, this tolerance may only be applied to<br>mixed products which have been made from two or<br>more basic textile materials, irrespective of<br>their share of the product.</p>
<p>The following are the basic textile materials:<br>silk,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;wool,</p>
<p>coarse animal hair,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fine animal hair,<br>horsehair,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;cotton,</p>
<p>paper-making materials and paper,<br>flax,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;true hemp,</p>
<p>jute and other textile bast fibres,<br>sisal and other textile fibres of the genus<br>Agave,</p>
<h6>224</h6>
<h6>Prop. 1992/93:22</h6>
<h6>Annex II to</h6>
<h6>Protocol B</h6>
<p>coconut, abaca, ramie and other vegetable<br>textile fibres,</p>
<p>synthetic man-made filaments,<br>artificial man-made filaments,<br>synthetic man-made staple fibres,<br>artificial man-made staple fibres.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>A yarn of heading No. 5205 made from cotton<br>fibres and synthetic staple fibres is a<br>mixed yarn. Therefore, non-originating<br>materials that do not satisfy the origin<br>rules may be used up to a weight of 10 * of<br>the yarn.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>A woollen fabric of heading No. 5112 made<br>from woollen yarn and synthetic yarn of<br>staple fibres is a mixed fabric. Therefore,<br>either non-originating synthetic yarn or<br>woollen yarn or a combination thereof that<br>does not satisfy the origin rules may be<br>used up to a weight of 10 % of the fabric</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>Tufted textile of heading No. 5802 made from<br>cotton yarn and cotton fabric is only a<br>mixed product if the cotton fabric is itself<br>a mixed fabric being made from two or more<br>different basic textile materials or if the<br>cotton yarns used are themselves mixtures.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>It the tufted textile concerned had been<br>made from cotton yarn and synthetic fabric,<br>then, obviously, two separate basic textile<br>materials would have been used.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>A carpet with tufts made both from<br>artificial yarns and tufts made from cotton<br>yarns and with a jute backing is a mixed<br>product because three basic textile<br>materials are used. Thus, any non-<br>originating materials that are used at a<br>later stage of manufacture than the rule<br>allows, may be used, provided their total<br>weight taken together does not exceed 10 %<br>of the weight of the textile materials in<br>the carpet. Thus, the jute backing, the<br>artificial yarns and/or the cotton yarns<br>could be imported at that stage of<br>manufacture, provided the weight conditions<br>are met.</p>
<p>225</p>
<p>15 Riksdagen 1992193. 1 saml. Nr 22. Del 1</p>
<p>6.3 &nbsp;In the case of products incorporating &quot;yarn made<br>of polyurethane segmented with flexible segments<br>of polyether whether or not gimped&quot; this<br>tolerance is 20 % in respect of this yarn.</p>
<p>6.4 &nbsp;In the case of products incorporating strip<br>consisting of a core of aluminium foil or of a<br>core of plastic film whether or not coated with<br>aluminium powder, of a width not exceeding 5 mm.,<br>sandwiched by means of an adhesive between two<br>films of plastic film, this tolerance is 30 * in<br>respect of this strip.</p>
<p>Note 7</p>
<p>7.1 &nbsp;In the case of those textile products, which are<br>marked in the List by a footnote referring to<br>this Introductory Note, textile materials, with<br>the exception of linings and interlinings, which<br>do not satisfy the rule set out in the List in<br>column 3 for the made-up product concerned may be<br>used provided that they are classified in a<br>heading other than that of the product and that<br>their value does not exceed 8 % of the ex-works<br>price of the product.</p>
<p>7.2 &nbsp;Any non-textile trimmings and accessories or<br>other materials used which contain textiles do<br>not have to satisfy the conditions set out in<br>column 3 even though they fall outside the scope<br>of paragraph 3 of Note 4.</p>
<p>7.3 &nbsp;In accordance with paragraph 3 of Note 4, any<br>non-originating non-textile trimmings and<br>accessories or other product, which do not<br>contain any textiles, may, anyway, be used freely<br>where they cannot be made from the materials<br>listed in column 3.</p>
<p>- For example:<br>If a rule in the List says that for a<br>particular textile item, such as a blouse,<br>yarn must be used, this does not prevent the<br>use of metal items, such as buttons, because<br>they cannot be made from textile materials.</p>
<p>7.4 &nbsp;Where a percentage rule applies, the value of<br>trimmings and accessories must be taken into<br>account when calculating the value of the non-<br>originating materials incorporated.</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>Annex II to</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>

<p>231</p>
<p>Prop. 1992/93:22</p>
<p>Annex II to</p>
<p>ProtocolB</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>HS<br>Heading<br>No.</p></td><td>
<p>Description of product</p></td><td>
<p>Working or processing carried out on<br>non-originating materials that confers<br>originating status</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>(1)</p></td><td>
<p>(2)</p></td><td>
<p>(3)</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>

<p>Each item in the set must satisfy the<br>rule which would apply to it if it<br>were not included in the set.<br>However, non-originating artides<br>may be incorporated provided their<br>total value does not exceed 15% of<br>the ex-works price of the set</p></td></tr>

<h5>Annex III to</h5>

<p>ANNEX III TO PROTOCOL B</p>
<p>MOVEMENT CERTIFICATE</p>
<p>1 Export* (Na» Ml</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GG0322/prop_199293__22-3.png" style="width:29pt;height:10pt;"/>
<p>000007)</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GG0322/prop_199293__22-4.png" style="width:150pt;height:47pt;"/>
<p>aad</p>
<p>3. Cocsigsee (Naaa, Ml addaaa, eotatry)<br>(Opdoad)</p>
<p>(jonen apprppriu* eouetriaa. pwi» of oouoioo<br>er urriioria)</p>
<p>4. Country, group of<br>countriei or terri-<br>tory in which the<br>produai art con-<br>tidertd u orig-<br>taiaof</p>
